sessions.question: What 'types' of narrative are there?
sessions.background: In our last meeting we identified several 'types' of narrative from our discussions.  Narratives that provide information, tackle misconceptions, identify similar situations or offer hope. What other types are there?
questions: Are any other core types of narrative?
What are the main features of each of these types? For example: when and why might they be useful, how often will they be consumed?
What might we do to maximise the impact of each type?

sessions.question: How should narratives be delivered?
sessions.background: We expect our intervention to deliver narratives as text, audio and video (with subtitle options). However we don't yet know what other forms will be useful, or what the range of options for delivering each of these should be.
questions: What other forms, beyond text, audio and video should we consider, and under what circumstances?
Are there situations where users will prefer longer or shorter narratives?
Will users prefer to consume one or more extracts from narratives that focus on a specific issue or to consume fuller, more expansive narratives? What will this depend on?
Will (and in what situations) will they want to consume a narrative more than once?
Will users want to consume multiple narratives that are narrated by, or focus on, the same person?

sessions.question: What makes a narrative feel 'authentic'?
sessions.background: We know that authenticity of a narrative will influence its impact. What are the key parts of a narrative that make it feel authentic? What makes it feel inauthentic?
questions: What influences the perception of authenticity? The narrator? The content? Or how well a narrative matches a user's expectations and experience?
Can we construct fictional but authentic narratives?
Is it more important that some 'types' of narrative are more authentic than others?

sessions.question: How will participants want to search for narratives?
sessions.background: We have already run a short session where participants tested a browse-based (YouTube-style) and chatbot (ChatGPT-style) based interface for discovering narratives. It raised a set of additional questions we'll explore in this session.
questions: Do participants always know what narratives they want?
Do certain 'types' of narrative (and expectations) require richer expressions of intent?

sessions.question: What are the implications of using chat-based systems?
sessions.background: We have a theory that chatting over text might be an effective way to help people discover narratives. We'd like to test this idea a little further in this session.
questions: Is it possible to ensure that the chatbot and participant keep discussions within the scope of the task?
Do conversational interfaces provide a more effective approach to discovering narratives than browse-based systems (if so, how/why)?
Do users trust chat-based interfaces (more or less than other interfaces)?
What are the risks of using conversational interfaces and can they be handled?

sessions.question: What is the role of reflection?
sessions.background: In our last in-person meeting, we noticed that some participants used our chat interface to discuss narratives that they had watched. Could this be an important or useful way to help people get more from narratives?
questions: Why do people want to discuss narratives they've watched?
Should we always encourage or expect reflection?
When will users want to reflect on narratives (just after watching or when searching for another one)?

sessions.question: How do we reduce the risk of narrative harms?
sessions.background: We know that there are various harms that may occur when users watch narratives including frustration, offence and feelings of isolation. We'd like to use this session to explore this issue further.
questions: What kinds of harms are possible and what are the risk factors (i.e. content, mismatching, common 'triggers')?
What mechanisms can we employ to reduce the risk of harms occurring?
What mechanisms can we employ to support users when harms occur?

sessions.question: How can we help people create their own narratives?
sessions.background: In our last meeting a few participants discussed sharing their own narratives. How can we help support this?
questions: What would your reasons be for wanting to share a narrative?
What would you want to say?
Is there more than one story that you'd like to tell?
